identificationModule.briefTitle: Natural History, Diagnosis, and Outcomes for Leukodystrophies
identificationModule.officialTitle: Natural History, Diagnosis, and Outcomes for Leukodystrophies

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The goals of this protocol is to diagnose, care for, and understand the clinical histories and outcomes of people with leukodystrophies.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
Inherited leukodystrophies affect close to 1 in 7500 children with mortality greater than 30%. Affected patients face additional serious medical complications including epilepsy, developmental regression, and intellectual disabilities. Diagnosis is difficult and requires the assistance of a specialist. Finally, identifying treatments and improving outcomes is complex.

The Western Leukodystrophy Project, which is part of the University of Utah and of Primary Children's Hospital, and which is a certified Leukodystrophy Care Network Center, provides a specialized resource for patients with leukodystrophies.

This clinical study assists with diagnosis of leukodystrophies; suggesting treatment options and implementing care guidelines, and improving outcomes for all patients by understanding the clinical histories and outcomes of affected patients..

bioSpec.description: Patients have the option to have a DNA sample or cell line sample biobanked.

primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Participants will be followed for the duration of the study (up to 20 years), with checks on average of once per year

secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Participants will be followed for the duration of the study (up to 20 years), with checks on average of once per year

secondaryOutcomes.description: Perform brain MRI to evaluate changes due to a leukodystrophy
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Participants will be followed for the duration of the study (up to 20 years), with an MRI performed at presentation and then repeated on average once every 5 years

secondaryOutcomes.description: Using sequencing to establish a genetic diagnosis
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Participants will be tested at presentation, and then re-tested for the duration of the study (up to 20 years), with re-testing on average of once per three years

secondaryOutcomes.description: Evaluate neurological changes due to leukodystrophy and response following a bone marrow
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Participants will be followed for the duration of the study (up to 20 years), with checks on average of once per year

secondaryOutcomes.description: Evaluate spasticity complications defined by the presence of increased tone (spasticity)
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Participants will be followed for the duration of the study (up to 20 years), with checks on average of once per year

secondaryOutcomes.description: Evaluate respiratory complications defined by the need for supplemental oxygen
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Participants will be followed for the duration of the study (up to 20 years), with checks on average of once per year

secondaryOutcomes.description: Evaluate hypotonia complications defined by the presence of hypotonia
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Participants will be followed for the duration of the study (up to 20 years), with checks on average of once per year

secondaryOutcomes.description: Evaluate bulbar complications defined by the presence of swallowing difficulties
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Participants will be followed for the duration of the study (up to 20 years), with checks on average of once per year

secondaryOutcomes.description: Evaluate cerebellar complications defined by the presence of ataxia or coordination problems
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Participants will be followed for the duration of the study (up to 20 years), with checks on average of once per year

secondaryOutcomes.description: Evaluate language complications defined by language impairment below age norms
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Participants will be followed for the duration of the study (up to 20 years), with checks on average of once per year

eligibilityModule.studyPopulation: Any person with an apparent inherited disease of white matter (except as excluded by the exclusion criteria).
